introduction.p: Recall that the subscripts on the coordinates in ~P_1(x_1,y_1)~ and ~P_2(x_2,y_2)~ just mean "first point" and "second point".

assemblage.title: Two-Point Formula for Slope
assemblage.p: The slope of the line joining points ~P_1(x_1,y_1)~ and ~P_2(x_2,y_2)~ is m = \dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \dfrac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}~~~~~~\text{if}~~~~x_2 \not= x_1

introduction.p: Because the y-intercept (0,b) is the "starting value" of a linear model, and its rate of change is measured by its slope,m, the equation for a linear model y = \text{starting value} + \text{rate} \times x can be expressed in symbols as y = b + mx

assemblage.title: Slope-Intercept Form
assemblage.p: If we write the equation of a linear function in the form, f (x) = b + mx then m is the slopeslope of the line, and b is the y-intercept.

statement.p: The temperature inside a pottery drying oven starts at 70 degrees and is rising at a rate of 0.5 degrees per minute. Write a function for the temperature, H, inside the oven after t minutes.

solution.p: At t=0, the temperature is 70 degrees, so b=70.
The slope is given by the rate of increase of H, so m=0.5.

statement.p: A perfect score on a driving test is 120 points, and you lose 4 points for each wrong answer. Write a function for your score, S, if you give n wrong answers.

solution.p: If n=0, your score is 120, so b=120.
Your score decreases by 4 points per wrong answer, so m=\dfrac{\Delta S}{\Delta n} = 4.

introduction.p: If we don't know the y-intercept of a line but we do know one other point and the slope, we can still find an equation for the line.

assemblage.title: Point-Slope Formula
assemblage.p: To find an equation for the line of slope m passing through the point (x_1,y_1), use the point-slope formula \dfrac{y-y_1}{x-x_1} = m or y-y_1=m(x-x_1)

subsection.title: 4. Graphing a linear equation by the point-slope method

introduction.p: If we know one point on a line and its slope, we can sketch its graph without having to make a table of values.

solution.p: Step1: Begin by plotting the y-intercept, (0,-2).

stack.p: Step 2: We use the slope, \dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \dfrac{3}{4}, to find another point on the line, as follows. Start at the point (0,-2) and move 3 units up and 4 units to the right. Plot a second point here, at (4,1).
Step 3: Find a third point by writing the slope as \dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \dfrac{-3}{-4}: from (0,-2), move down 3 units and 4 units to the left. Plot a third point here, at (-4,-5).

solution.p: Finally, draw a line through the three points.

statement.p: Graph the line of slope \dfrac{-1}{2} that passes through (-3,-2).

solution.p: Step 1: Begin by plotting the point (-3,-2).

stack.p: Step 2: Use the slope, \dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \dfrac{-1}{2}, to find another point on the line, as follows. Start at the point (-3,-2) and move 1 unit down and 2 units to the right. Plot a second point here, at (-1,-3).
Step 3: Find a third point by writing the slope as \dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \dfrac{1}{-2}: from (-3,-2), move 1 unit up and 2 units to the left. Plot a third point here, at (-5,-1).

solution.p: Finally, draw a line through the three points.
